values:
Date: August 3
Symbol: HURN
Bought: 13.75
Sold: 14.41
Grade: B
Notes: This stock gapped down from the 50s on news of possible accounting fraud.  It very volatile, but moved up pretty strongly from 12.  Sadly I didn't notice it till it was in the mid 13s.  I got in at 13.75.  

It tried for 14 and came off a little then went through 14 strongly.  It took a couple tries for it to get through 14.50 as well.  Then it topped out around 14.75 and started to come back down.  I waited to see whether it would hold 14.50 since that had been a previous congestion area.  As soon as it didn't, I got out with a decent trade.

At the same time I was watching this (before I got in), I was also watching WNC which had moved up and crossed the magic 1 mark to around 1.04.  I only had one trade to make.  HURN was a lot more volatile so I ended up picking it.  WNC topped out around 1.24 before coming off which is a much bigger move percentage wise, so I probably should have played it instead.  One of these days I won't be under PDT and I'll be able to do both.  :-)  Still, it's not a bad thing to only be watching one for the moment.  I can really focus on it that way.  Also, it's never a bad thing to be selective.  There's just times when both opportunities are good.

Date: July 28
Symbol: TPTX
Bought: 0.220
Sold: 0.208
Grade: C
Notes: There wasn't that much to this trade.  I should have bought when I first noticed it at .18.  If I had then I probably would have made at least a little money on the trade.  Instead I top ticked it at 0.22.  At least when it started to drop I had the good sense to get out immediately with a small loss.

Date: July 28
Symbol: IMMU
Bought: 5.04
Sold: 5.22
Grade: B
Notes: I bought this one as it crossed 5.  I actually did a pretty good job and sold it pretty close to the top of its move.  It then dropped all the way back to 5 before bouncing back up even higher.  Too bad I was out of trades.

Date: July 23
Symbol: LLBO
Bought: 0.0091
Sold: 0.016
Grade: A
Notes: I noticed this stock while scanning the market at the end of the day yesterday.  It had gone from 0.001 to 0.0069 with huge volume.  This had basically been flatlined for months at 0.001 with no volume, so it seemed likely it would run again today.  I started watching it this morning and it had already bounced off the 0.009 level once (and yesterday once) so there was definite resistance around that level.  I figured if it broke through that resistence I would get in.

To complicate matters I was also watching a stock called BIEL which had resistence around 0.065.  I only had one day trade left, so I couldn't buy both.  BIEL just barely broke through resistence to 0.066 but came back off a little bit.  Moments later LLBO broke through to 0.0091 and held there so I got in.

It went up slowly but very steadily over the next nail-biting half an hour while I asked myself about a million times whether I should take my profit and run.  I wanted to wait till the first signs of weakness but there were none!  It just kept going up, hundredth of a penny by hundredth of a penny.

At the very end of its rise it started accelerating which was a good sign the end of the run was coming.  It hit 0.017 and started coming off and I hit the sell button.  Then the most infuriating thing happened.  My sell order didn't go through immediately.  I suppose this is a Pink Sheets penny stock so I should probably expect some delays of execution but I was jumping up and down and shouting at the computer for about a minute watching the stock come down before my order finally went through and I got out at 0.016.  With a 75% profit in about half an hour I guess I have nothing to complain about.

It found support at 0.011 and started back up and as I write this it's back at 0.017.  If I had a day trade left I would be watching for it to either break that resistance level (in which case I would buy) or make a double top and come back down (in which case I would short).  I guess we'll see, but I'm pretty happy with my trade for now.

Date: July 21
Symbol: MNI
Bought: 0.850
Sold: 0.841
Grade: A
Notes: This one popped on good volume, so I got in.  It went up to 0.87 but then started acting flaky so I sold it.  I give myself an A on this trade since it proceeded to fall all the way to 0.72 and I got out early  with only a very small loss.  Sometimes cutting your losses quickly is the hardest thing to do and yet the most important.

Date: July 21
Symbol: CIT
Sold Short: 1.18
Covered: 0.85
Grade: A
Notes:  CIT Group is the beleagured small business lender that the government has recently refused to pump money into.  Lots of activity in the stock (stocks on the verge of bankruptcy are often quite volatile).  When the market opened, the stock was not allowed to trade because a news release was coming out.  I think lots of people probably thought it was bad news and put in sell orders that just built up until the news actually hit.  As soon as the stock was opened (maybe half an hour after the market opened), it fell like a rock and I shorted it.  It fell from 1.35 very fast and I was lucky to get in at 1.18.  It bounced just below 0.80 and I covered it almost perfectly at the bottom.  

The news was not bankruptcy so all those early sellers/shorts turned into buyers.  I would have liked to go long at that point and ride it back up (it came all the way back up to 1.17 before falling off a bit and settling) but I was out of day trades for the week.  Too bad.  I will be happy when I am no longer under the PDT restrictions.  As a function of time spent, this is probably my largest profit yet.  Almost 40% in less than 5 minutes.  I only wish I had put more money into the trade.

Okay I'm going to post several here to catch up.

Date: 7/8/09 - 7/13/09
Symbol: AIG
Sold Short: 13.42, 9.42
Covered: 11.82, 11.45, 10.49, 12.86
Grade: A
Notes:  I noticed the sharp downtrend in AIG and decided to short it.  Okay, I was a little late to the party, but I still made out pretty well.  This was was intended as a short term trade, not a day trade.  The stock broke down sharply the day after I shorted it and I covered a large part of my short position in stages (below 12, 11.50, and 10.50) for a very nice profit.  The next day it broke down even farther.  Unwisely I shorted a little more (but still much less than my original position) instead of covering my remaining short.  The next trading day it reversed and started to rise sharply (basically a short covering rally).  I should have covered when it started rising but I waited till the next day.  As it continued to rise, I covered the last bit of my short position for a loss, but (wisely as it turns out) decided to swing the trade, which brings me to the next trade.

Date: 7/13/09
Symbol: AIG
Bought: 12.86
Sold: 14.10
Grade: A
Notes: So I covered my short and went long on the short squeeze, which made for a very nice day trade.  I made back my small loss on the last bit of the short trade and then some.  Then I tried shorting again too early which takes me to the next trade.

Date: 7/13/09
Symbol: AIG
Sold Short: 14.20
Sold: 14.65
Grade: C
Notes: I tried swinging this trade too early.  I thought it was breaking down and set a stop loss right above the day's previous high before going to the gym.  The stop was hit and my short was covered for a small loss.  The stock continued going up, so I guess that wasn't a bad thing.  The next day it gapped up and then started its real downward sllide (unfortunately so far without me).

Date: 7/15/09
Symbol: TRGT
Sold Short: 6.24
Sold: 6.67
Grade: C
Notes: This stock gapped up huge at the open, and often after such a big gap, a stock fades back down a bit off its highs to close at least some of the gap.  I was looking to go short and it appeared like it was fading so I shorted it.  Unfortunately it was a fake out and the stock took off for a 2nd leg up.  I covered quickly  for a small loss, but if only I weren't under the PDT rule (3 day trades per week and mine were all used up) I would have swung it and gone long for a profit.  Alas, but no crying over trades not taken I suppose.

Date:   July 8
Symbol: LFBG
Bought: 0.063
Sold:   0.061
Grade:  N/A
Notes:  So this was a loss that would have been a gain if it hadn't been for some technical difficulties.  I use Interactive Brokers (IB) and they have 2 trading interfaces, a full-featured Java app called TraderWorkstation (TWS) and a crummy web interface called WebTrader.  Needless to say I use TWS.  

I bought LFBG at 0.063 and it moved up very nicely to 0.070.  I was staring at it wondering if that was all it had in it and it was time to sell and the software stopped working (as in it lost it's connection to the server).  I closed it and tried to reopen.  It wouldn't log in.  I began to panic.  I tried to log in several more times.  I checked my internet connection just to make sure I was connected.  I rebooted my computer and rebooted the wireless router.  All to no avail.  

Then I remembered the web interface and tried to log in.  It wouldn't log in either.  So now I'm really panicking because I have no idea what's happening with that stock.  I went on IB's website looking for support and found they have a support chat service, so I logged in to that and waited for a customer rep.

While I'm waiting I remember I have my work laptop at home so I start that up.  Right as the tech support guy gets on chat I log in to the web interface on my laptop which thankfully seems to work and close the trade for a small loss.  So then I'm chatting with the support guy and he tells me that Verizon has blocked some ports and there are lots of people who have Verizon for an ISP who are having this same problem this morning and I should go talk to them.  He also tells me that the web trading interface doesn't work with Chrome, only IE and Firefox which was why I couldn't get into that on my desktop but could on my laptop.  Okay lesson learned on that one.

So now I'm wondering if Verizon has purposely blocked these ports or if they are having technical difficulties.  I try to log into several different websites and only some of them work.  All google sites seemed to work but LJ and several others didn't.  So I figured it was probably just an outage between some geographical locations in the country or something like that.  This was confirmed when I came home from lunch and everything worked perfectly again.  Stupid Verizon.

When I looked at the chart of LFBG aftwards, 0.070 was indeed its top.  I started coming down fairly slowly after that and I probably would have gotten out at 0.069 or 0.068 if I had been able to.

Takeaways from this experience:
1.  If TWS goes down I can close trades though WebTrader, but only if I use Firefox.
2.  When I have enough money I'll fund several brokerage accounts so that I'm not SOL if one of them stops working.
3.  The market (and circumstances) always works hard to act in such a way as to screw as many people as possible.  Don't be one of those people.  :-)

So for the moment I'm going to post a trading journal here. I'll probably move it to a different blog eventually, but I already have this one so its convenient. :-)

I think I'll grade myself on each trade with the following scale:
A - Good trade. Made the most of a good opportunity and generally exited with a nice gain.
B - Okay trade.  Made some sort of minor error in execution or traded a sub-par setup resulting in only a minor gain.
C - Mediocre trade.  Made a larger execution error or cut loss from a poor setup resulting in a minor loss.
D - Poor trade.  Made a really stupid move resulting in a large loss.

PNX5.555.61BGot in on nice uptrend with good volume.  
Stock made small double top at which point I should
have gotten out in the 5.70s.  Instead I waited a bit too long
but still got out with profit.  Afterwards, it came all the way down back
to the 5.10x where it started the day.

So here's my story about attempting to buy an iPhone yesterday.  I showed up at the mall Friday morning about 7:45.  There is both an AT&T store and an Apple store in the mall.  I had previously visited an AT&T store and they had informed me that it would be easier for me to get an iPhone at the Apple store because the AT&T stores would have very limited inventory.

Anyway, so I walked past the 20-person line at the AT&T store and joined the 90-person line at the Apple store (which subsequently turned into about an 120-person line I think).  The Apple folks were very nice, talked to everyone, told us what we had to have with us (credit card, ID, SS#, previous wireless number and password if you were a new AT&T customer and wanted to retain your old number).  They also provided free coffee and bottled water to everyone in line which was nice.  They assured us when I asked that they had MORE than enough iPhones for everyone in the line.  So far, so good.

So I figure I've been in lines at theme parks way longer than this one.  I looked to me like in a theme park this would take about 20 minutes and so I was expecting about an hour's wait after they started.  8:00 arrived and the first group of maybe 5 - 10 people went into the store.  The rest of us waited.... and waited...  40 minutes after the first group had gone in, I decided to give up.  I did have to work that day and I couldn't afford to wait in line until 3:00 in the afternoon.

On my way out I happened to go by the AT&T store which appeared to have just sold out of the 50 or iPhones they had had.  So I could have had one if I had waited in the shorter AT&T line.  :(  Also, the AT&T salesperson kindly informed me that if you have any sort of discount on your account (which I do) that you can't activate at the Apple store anyway.  So even if I had waited forever in the line at the Apple store, I would not have been able to buy the phone there.  Grrrr....

So anyway, reading online what really happened, it appears that Apple did not sufficiently prepare their software system for the flood of people wanting to activate the phone at the same time as the flood of original iPhone users wanting to download the software update that came out on the same day as the new iPhone's release.  Probably the reason that the first group was still in the Apple store when I left was that they were still trying to activate their phones and couldn't.  Apparently the AT&T store was not having as much of a problem because it looked like they had already activated more phones than Apple.  Of course all the AT&T folks had to do was ensure they were activated on AT&T's network; they probably weren't even messing with activating them on the Apple side and just letting people do that at home.

The good news is that I should be able to get an iPhone sometime next week and I'm sure Apple will have their servers up and running strong by then so in the long run it won't be a problem.

Wel-come to the Social. And wel-come to the UGLY! I mean seriously folks does Microsoft really expect this hideous 60s brick to sink Apple? Paul Thurrott's Windows Supersite has a nice photo gallery here: Zune photo gallery

I can just imagine someone at Microsoft saying, "Hmmm, how will we differentiate our product line from Apple? I know! Let's make it ugly! And even bigger than an iPod! And how about some nasty pink, brown, and orange 60s packaging! Throw in some Engrish and it'll sell like teh hot ca-ke!" Seriously, if you want to compete with Apple, you have to be PRETTY. Lots of mp3 players have more features than iPods and Apple still controls 80% of the mp3 player market because they have STYLE. This is obviously a foreign concept to those at Microsoft.
Check out this truly bizare internet money making story: Million Dollar Homepage

Well I am really enjoying my new job! Thus far I have been reading/learning/editing the installation guide and training manual for our software. I helps the developers to have a fresh perspective from someone who's never used the software before. Anyway, this is a funny article passed along to me by my friend Stefan: In Defense of Geeks or Ten Reasons Why You Should Date a Geek

So now I have 2 companies making me job offers!  I got one offer for $25k / year and then another for $37k / year and then the first company upped their offer to $37k / year plus a 5% signing bonus.  Decisions, decisions, decisions.

In other news I am at my cousin's house about an hour south of Seattle with her and her husband and his sister and my sister.  It's been a splendid Christmas with lots of food and sugar and presents and all that good stuff.  I'm making my famous chocolate souffle for dessert after Christmas lunch today.  I haven't made it in over a year, but hopefully it will turn out well *knocks on wood*.  :-)  Merry Christmas all!

Copy to your journal and answer.... 1. My username is ____ because ____. 2. My journal is titled ____ because ____. 3. My subtitle is ____ because ____. 4. My friends page is called ____ because ____. 5. My default userpic is ____ because ___. So here are my answers: 1.  My username is lordofthewarcry because I am Diomedes.  It's all in Homer folks. 2.  My journal is titled Theophilos because it means (basically) "friend of God" in Greek. 3.  My subtitle is emoi gar zen christos kai apothanein kerdos. which means "For to me, to live is Christ and to die gain."  It's a quote from Paul (from Philippians) in the original Greek. 4.  My friends page is called friends because I didn't take the time to think of anything creative to call it. 5.  My default userpic is (the one on this post) because I like to read ancient Greek (do you sense a trend here?). And in other news....  I HAVE A JOB OFFER!!  Woohoo!!

Okay and here's another problem.  We believe that people should live up to all the light they have and that God will honor them for it.  This is typically used to justify those who do not know anything about the Bible or Christianity and yet perhaps they lived up to the best that they knew and so God will honor that as service to Himself and take them to Heaven.

This evening it was brought to my attention that perhaps this concept could be used in the reverse situation though.  What if you have someone who truly believes that something is a sin EVEN when it isn't.  They are in a more strict or restrictive religious system than God intended.  Then they conciously do that thing and so rebel against God.  Are they then sinning because they are rebelling even though the thing they do is not a sin?

One's initial reaction is perhaps yes because rebellion against God is in fact sin.  However, what if we take the situation farther and say that they are in a completely non-Christian religious setting and they rebel against the god or gods of that setting.  Is it sin then?  What if they rebel against a heathen diety that is telling them to do something awful?  The concept doesn't seem to me to stand up under these types of conditions.  Even if they have been trained to think that it is the "right thing" to obey this heathen diety, that this is in fact God.  Okay you could make the argument that because they recognize the thing as awful they are then following the principle of living up to all the light they have.  But what if they disobey the heathen diety in something that is not really awful but rather just arbitrary.  What then?

Of course there is the whole question of whether God does in fact in every situation give some indication, be it twinge of concience or something else, what the truly right path is.  I think that for all people that ARE still saveable and have not yet been irredeemably lost that God will at SOME point in their lives give them an indication of what the right thing to do really is.  I'm not sure I can seriously think that in EVERY bad thing they ever did if they were raised as a heathen that God gave them some indication of what the right thing to do was.  Nor can I think that God could accept some of the awful forms of service people make to heathen dieties as proper praise since they knew no better.  Rather that at some point in their lives He showed Himself in some way and gave them a choice to accept or deny.

The pastor at the Beaverton church today preached about giving to the poor and needy.  I thought he did an excellent job, bringing out that when Jesus says "The poor you will always have among you" concerning Mary's gift, Jesus was actually referring to some verses in Deuteronomy that talk about giving freely to the poor even when the year of Jubilee (and debt cancellation) is just around the corner.

Anyway, though, he started the sermon off with some statistics about the world, you know the kind that start off, "If there were just 100 people in the world here is how they would look, 52 would be women, 48 would be men, etc., etc., etc."  However, he said one minute that 30 would be white and 70 would not be, then he said in the next sentence that 61 would be asian, 13 african, etc.  Now if you do the math, 61 + 13 + ... = 74+ which is more than the previous 70.  I *assume* that he got his statistics from separate sources, one referring to actual geographical locations (a large part of Russia is in Asia and is white for example) and one to actual racial groups (white and non-white).  Or on the other hand he could have just been confused; I dunno.  I tend to think that pastors who want to use a lot of numbers in their sermons ought to get someone to proofread for them that actually understands numbers, but that's a little cynical I know.  The rest of the sermon was quite good so I'm not really complaining though.

So I was reading the first chapter of Mark this morning and it mentions what was apparently the first leper to come to Jesus for healing.  Jesus tells the man (as He told so many people He healed) not to tell anyone about it.  Of course the leper disobeyed that request and "began to proclaim it freely and to spread the news around, to such an extent that Jesus could no longer publicly enter a city, but stayed out in unpopulated areas."

Now I usually have thought this was because so many people were mobbing Jesus that He couldn't get into a city.  However another reason occured to me that I think makes more sense.  Perhaps the reason Jesus asked the leper not to tell and the reason He then couldn't go into the cities was because He had touched a leper.  I mean people weren't normally allowed even to approach lepers since the disease was so contageous and is it not possible that the cities barred Jesus from entering because they were afraid He would spread disease into their walls?

Then the passage continues with the really amazing part that "they were coming to Him from everywhere."  Despite the fact that people, especially city officials were afraid of Jesus entering their walls, He continued to draw people from all around to hear the message and receive the healing.  Really amazing I must say.

Then again this still doesn't answer the general question of why Jesus asked some people not to tell about how He had healed them and yet commisioned others to do exactly that.  I think the question bears to have some more study on each individual circumstance in which Jesus made a request one way or the other.

I should update my journal more.  Recently I was perusing someone else's journal and found an entry in a language I completely didn't recognize (which is not an alltogether common occurance actually; even if I can't read the language I usually know what it is).  Anyway, that made me think that I really ought to post entries on here in Japanese or greek or some other language sometime.  But then I thought, but who would ever know what they say except me?  I mean, it's really no fun to post secret messages unless at least one other person can read them.  Oh well.  

Anyway, I'm back, maybe I'll post more often again from now on.  I'm living in Portland, OR now for those that didn't know.  Beautiful place I must say.  Anyway, later!

Well today after I had corrected my stupidity with dates (my sister gets here a day later than I had thought so I had to change our hotel and bullet train reservations which turned out to be much less trouble than my panicy mind at first imagined).  Anyway, as I was saying AFTER I had corrected my stupid mistake which ended up costing us no extra money, I celebrated by going out and spending money!  Horray!

I went to see the new Naruto movie which hit the Japanese theatres a couple weeks ago. <lj-cut text="Almost completely spoiler free impressions"> Now the first Naruto movie was okay, but not spectacular, so I didn't hold out real high hopes for the 2nd one.  Still, I'm in Japan, and I might as well take advantage of my only ever lifetime opportunity to see Naruto on the big screen (unless I visit here in 2006 when the next one comes out).  My expectations were just about spot on.  While of course I could only understand some bits of the dialogue, I still got most of the plot just fine, which was a pretty tired affair involving ancient alien technology and some crazy guy wanting to take over the world (or destroy it or just become super powerful; wasn't too clear on that).  In typical Naruto fashion, the villian was quite evil, but his underling was a much more empathetic character (won't tell you what happens to him in the end though).  Similar to the first movie, the animation was not up to the quality of the TV series, although this time around, the characters were mostly animated by hand on top of really badly done CG backgrounds which was even worse than the first movie I think.  Also, it appeared that the writers and animators reached their time deadline about half way through the movie, so the 2nd half was definitely inferior to the beginning and the ending was prettty dumb which was also not unexpected from the first movie.

Still, it did have its redeeming qualities.  It had a heavy dose of Gaara for example, who was as scary-cool as ever (I was hoping for just a little more of him in the last few scenes I'll admit but he had his share of the spot light).  There were also a number of pretty well done fight scenes, which were fun to watch.  They kept the cast pretty small so we got to see everyone show their moves (Sakura, Naruto, Shikamaru, Gaara, and Kankuro were the only regular Naruto characters present).  Naruto had his signature moves although nothing too special (where on earth has his giant frog summoning gone?  He hasn't used that in forever in either the anime or manga!).  </lj-cut>

A note of interest on Japanese theatres for those who have never been to one.  First they are quite expensive ($17 is the normal price although women on Wednesdays and everyone on the first day of the month and children all cost $9 and sometimes you can find discount tickets at the convenience stores).  Second, people are extremely quiet and polite.  The theatre I was in today was stuffed full of elementary school kids and they were quiet as mouses through the whole movie, which would never ever happen in the US.  Thirdly, seats are usually (but as I found today not always) assigned.  And finally people sit through the entire credit role generally without making a sound or moving a muscle to leave (well I suppose if you have to pay so darned much you want to get as much as possible out of the thing right?).  Anyway, it is definitely a nicer experience, albeit a more expensive one, than US theatres are.  Oh and the theatres are generally cleaner too.  Oh and for American movies, you usually have the choice between Japanese subbed or dubbed, which is nice for all us who want to hear our movies in English (needless to say this choice is not available for Japanese movies like Naruto).

Oh and in other news I also bought the Naruto Official Fan Book (used! $3.50!) which means that I now know how to make all the hand seals!  I didn't know before that they are actually patterned after the animals in the Chinese zodiac.  Ya learn something new everyday.  ;->
Nuff said.  ;->

Okay I just checked online and the moon rises at 10:30 IN THE MORNING and sets at 10:40 at night here, so it's no wonder I don't see it.  It has nothing to do with smog or clouds and everything to do with it only being up during the day.  That really is weird.

I am very weirded out at the moment.  In the evenings I often go for a walk to help my food settle and relax before going to bed.  I have a set route I follow, which goes through a mostly residential area with very little traffic and a nice path.  It takes me about 45 minutes, so I recon it's between 2 and 3 miles long probably.

Anyway, there are a lot of houses and apartments along this route, but I think the most cats I've ever seen out was maybe 2.  Tonight I saw at least 7 and maybe more.  And they weren't all in one area either, they were scattered all along the entire route.  They were all well fed looking and some had collars so I'm fairly certain they were all owned by people.  But they were all out on the road or side walk, and they all seemed, well, kind of agitated.  A couple were friendly and let me pet them or followed me a little way down the street.  But even those didn't act relaxed like a cat might who is sitting out in front of its own house on a quiet night.

I tried to see if there was a full moon tonight, but I couldn't tell.  You can't often see the moon in Tokyo because of the clouds and smog and tall buildings all around.  Tonight was too cloudy.  Maybe The Big One is about to hit Tokyo and topple all those skyscrapers and sink part of it into the sea.  I dunno.  Maybe it was all a coincidence, but it did seem awfullly strange....

Quote of the evening (from Philip Yancy, The Bible Jesus Read):  "After examining his own life and toying with the notion of an unjust God, Job arrives at a different formula that on the surface makes no sense:  'Suffering comes from God.  God is just.  I am innocent.'"  Wow that made me laugh a lot.  Maybe it's just because I've been teaching Job in my Bible classes all year and this really rings true from the book, but for some reason that was really funny.

Oh Oh I just had a funny thought that I ought to write down before I forget it.  It's really weird but I think that cell phones are actually a barrier to people learning to use computers in japan  It's surprising how many people are illiterate when it comes to personal computers in such an advanced country, but most of them only use their cell phones for stuff like e-mail so they don't have to use a regular computer.  In america the computer has LOTS of uses of course but still I think the main use that makes EVERYONE own a computer is communication; even grandma buys one so she can e-mail the grandkids; in japan they dont have to do that.  Grandma may own an MD player and a cell phone, but she doesn't need a PC.  Anyway, that's my odd thought of the day.

Then he saw The Book.  And he DESIRED her.  And he decided to spend his paycheck and buy her.  But he thought to himself, "If she is alone in my bag with the older books she may become picked on."  So he found 2 more which he also DESIRED to be her helpmates.  And so he bought them, all three.  And he took them home.  Thus the prophecy fortold of the man, that he would spend all his paycheck upon books, was fulfilled on the 8th day of the 7th month.  Amen.

Okay let's create a very weird philosophy based on the opposition of weight and lightness.  Then we'll justify it with very odd leaps in logic (for example:  "In love poetry, the woman desires the weight of the man's body on her so this means that 'weight' must be more desirable than 'lightness'").  Then we'll create a fictional story based on our strange, rather unjustifyable worldview based on two characters whose psychology we create and expoit in our story to make some sort of point about said worldview.  Ugh, anyway....
What a wretched, miserable book I'm listening to.  Not recommended.

Our school's secretary's mother is in the hospital right now.  She has some sort of bone problem, which, after I looked it up in my electronic dictionary I still had no idea what it is (no not osteo porosis or anything obvious like that).  Anyway, today I was going to go and visit her and take her flowers because she's a really nice person.  So I thought "Hmmm, what kind of flowers are best for someone in the hospital?  Something in a pot so it can sit there and be pretty for a while and something bright and cheerful."  So I got some bright yellow marigolds in a pot and headed happily towards the hospital.

Well first I had to stop at the English school to get the room number and I met some of our students' moms out front.  They asked me what I was doing and I explained what the flowers were for.  Then they very hesitantly and tactfully told me that that was a very bad idea.  Apparently potted flowers for someone in the hospital are a big no no in Japan because the fact that the flower will live for a long time symbolizes a long stay in the hospital.  Also, yellow flowers have some association with funerals and are also a big no no for hospital patients.  Two strikes and I'm out.

Of course the gracious mothers made it very clear that the lady would understand since I am a foreigner and not to worry about it, but after knowing I just couldn't do it.  Fortunately the flowers weren't at all expensive, but I didn't have time to go and get more flowers and make the hospital visit and make it to class after that so I had to give up on it for today.  Too bad.  Hopefully I'll get around to trying again tomorrow.

Even after being here for over 10 months now, culture can still sneak up on you when you're least expecting it.  Well now I know better.  Tomorrow it will be long stem, cut, and maybe bright red or blue.  Try try again.

Hehehe, I just finished listening to Moving Pictures by Terry Pratchett.  I think it was one of the funniest of his novels that I've read.  Really really good, and just plain funny.  If you want a good book to amuse you for a while, give it a try.  :-D

Hmmm, you buy a bunch of computers for high school students, you install a bunch of software to spy on them and prevent them from making much actual use of the computers, including disabling chat and e-mail, you proceed to give them the computer and allow them to take it home in the evenings and use it on their own internet connection.  Then you slap them with a felony charge when the smarter ones disable the spying software so they can actually use the stupid computer?!  Did I mention that these are Apple iBooks and that the spying/disabling software put on them had 1 master password for everyone in the school which was apparently leaked fairly early on (surprise, surprise)?  I mean, the whole plan is pretty flawed to begin with, starting from where you disable e-mail and allow them to take the computer home at night.  But a felony charge??  It used to be that breaking a school rule got you sent to the principal's office and maybe if you kept doing it you would get on probation and eventually kicked out.  These days apparently it's felony charges.  Good grief.  Full article is here and their computer usage policy is here.

I was taking a walk this evening and saw the strangest looking animal walking down the road.  At first I thought it must be a ferret that had escaped from it's owner's house, but then when I got closer to it I realized it was larger than any ferret I have ever seen.  It was as big as a medium sized cat, with a basic ferret-like shape and a medium length tail.  I think it must have been either a small fox or a large weasel, or something in the weasel family.  It was just trotting down the road in the middle of residential Tokyo as happy as you please and I was walking about 15 feet behind it for 2 or 3 minutes until it turned and went under a gate into someone's yard.  I didn't get a good look at the head and only saw it in the light of street lamps since it was dark outside, but definitely not a cat and I'm almost sure it wasn't a normal ferret.  Very odd to see something like that around here.  I suppose it could have been a pet weasel or something of that variety, but I wonder that someone would let it go wandering around like that if it were a pet.  Abbie any ideas?

You know I think some of the most interesting livejournal entries, those that spark the longest and most interesting conversations, are those made about various intellectual subjects, religious or philosophical generally, which can easily by disagreed with or which ask for opinions on interesting topics.  I love reading and commenting on these types of posts, which most often seem to come up on <lj user="davidlurie">'s and <lj user="erunion">'s journals (thanks guys!).

However, despite the fact that I find these types of entries most interesting, I hardly ever post such entries myself.  I wonder why that is sometimes.  Of course it's not really much different with real life conversations; I like having long involved conversations about things like that, but I rarely start such conversations.  Maybe one reason is that I am generally a defender of orthodoxy (well SDA orthodoxy at any rate), and a lot of my opinions tend to fall basically in line with what one might consider orthodox SDA theology.  Maybe another reason is that I already know what I think about a lot of things, and I don't tend to share my opinions unless someone asks for them which is not that often (no one is disliked as much as the guy who can't shut up with his opinions about everything).

Usually when I prepare for a Bible study or for teaching the Sabbath school lesson, my preparation notes tend to look like a long list of scripture passages with a long list of questions indented under each passage.  Some of those questions I think I have good answers too (although the questions are never rhetorical or stupid-simple like the SS lesson's often are) and some I don't.  I like to teach that way; by asking my students what I see as the hardest questions I can think of about a particular passage.  The questions don't always have good answers, but that makes it all the more interesting.  Maybe I just need to start posting some of those questions from my Bible classes on Livejournal.  Often times though, one really needs to have read the whole book up to a particular point (and sometimes even the whole book after that point) to provide intelligent commentary on questions like that.  Anyway, maybe I'll try that sometime.  Sorry for such a rambling entry, have a good day all!

Recently I watched the third (hopefully last) in the new star wars series.  Well I can say that I definitely liked it better than the abysmal Episode II, but not as much as I liked Episode I (or any of the old star wars movies for that matter).  It does run into the same problems that I've had with all of the new movies though, namely that they hire no name actors who couldn't pull off saying a line naturally to save their lives, and the lines aren't that great to begin with.  I mean one of the big attractions in the older movies was having Han Solo (oooo Harrison Ford!) making smart remarks all the time.  The new movies unfortunately have no actors with such abilities (either humor wise or acting wise).  Anyway, though, it wasn't that bad; I did enjoy it, especially towards the end when you got to see how all the loose ends shape up the way that they would start in the old series.  I'll have to go back and watch some of the older ones again one of these days.

You know there's something I can't figure out.  People seem to like to have me around when I'm there.  And they certainly want me around if there's something they want someone to speak up for them about.  But when they want to go out and have fun, they never invite me.  I love to go out and do stuff just as much as the next guy, but people just don't want me around when they want to have fun.  Life is lonely.

This is an interview from .  If you want to be interviewed, leave a comment with the word "beep" in it. 1. What would you do if your next-door neighbours had a vociferous and incessant peacock? Would you do it with a gun, knife, or poison? Colonel Mustard in the Drawing Room with the Candlestick of course.  :-P 2. In what way(s) are you most like Hatake Kakashi? Hmmm, I'm usually fairly even keel as far as my mood goes.  I very rarely get mad, but when I do, fear me!  :-> 3. Reality: a relatively unimportant intrusion or a good place to be? Why? Reality is a good place to be because true reality is where God is. 4. Have you ever eaten sushi icecream? If not, would you try it? LOL!  No I have not, but if it was veggie then yeah I'd try it! I think it would be nasty, but I'd at least try it.  :-) 5. What do you most like and dislike about SDA culture, and why are you still in the church? Hmmm, that's a tough one, especially since right now I am living in a different SDA culture (namely Japanese SDA culture).  I suppose your question is referring to American SDA culture.  The thing I most dislike:  the opposition of "liberal" and "conservative" parties within the church.  I'm not saying I favor either side; I'm saying I dislike the fact that there are sides at all.  There shouldn't be, although that sort of division seems inevitable sometimes.  Divisions like that do a great disservice to God's work in my opinion.  Thing I most like:  the fact that, despite a lot of complacence and deadweight, there is still an emphasis on mission in many parts of SDA culture.  You don't find it everywhere, but there are still a lot of great people who are interested in doing God's work.

Well I am not the sort of SDA who will cry "End of time!" everytime the stock market takes a dip.  However, there are some rather grim consequences to the recently passed Real ID act.  There's an interesting article on it here.  Basically the gist is that the act sets aside the Constitutional right of judicial review for actions taken by Homeland Security in certain situations.  Not that there's such a likelihood that judicial review will be needed in those circumstances, but if one side of the system of checks and balances can so easily prevent itself from being checked or balanced, it may bode ill in the future.

Well I've been trying to avoid it, but this quiz has surfaced on so many of my friends' blogs that I have finally given in to peer pressure.  However I don't think the result will be comprehensible to most of you, but here goes.

1. Grab the nearest book.

2. Open the book to page 123.

3. Find the fifth full sentence.

4. Post the text of the sentence in your journal along with these instructions.

5. Don't search around for the coolest book you can find. Use what's actually nearest to you.

The book is my new copy of the Bible in Japanese and it's Exodus 18:2-3 (conveniently put into Roomaji for those who can't read kana and kanji:

"Moose no shuu to etoro wa, moose ga saki ni kaeshte ita tsuma no shipora to, futari no musuko o tsurete kita."

For the benefit of those of you who might want to know what those verses say, here it is from the NIV:

"2 After Moses had sent away his wife Zipporah, his father-in-law Jethro received her 3 and her two sons."

If you aren't a member of the group, you should definitely go check out the new narnia trailer.  It shows a lot more of the movie than any previous trailers or screen shots.  It looks good, and it looks like they're actually following the book pretty closely, since all the scenes look like they were pulled straight out of the book.  One can't be sure till it comes out, but I'm happy with how it looks so far.  :-)

Japanese people really like mayonaise.  And they eat it with really weird things, like noodles.  Fried soba noodles with mayo and boiled cabbage is a favourte dish.

They also really like pickles.  And they pickle everything from radishes to carrots to sour plums.  Pickles are a very traditional food with Japanese people, while I'm not sure about mayo; it was probably brought here a long time ago by early europeans.  Anyway, whatever the origin it is here to stay.

Top 3 reasons why Japanese people are wimps:

1.  They go to the hospital at the drop of a hat.  Literally, they do.  "You have a headache today?  Oh why don't you go to the hospital?"  I mean they go to the hospital for everything.

2.  They are obsessed with things that might be dangerous.  I mean so much so that they have told me that I ought to turn off the water to my washing machine, my hot water heater, and the gas to my stove when I'm not using them "just in case."  I have been lectured by grade school children about how the game we were playing was not safe enough.  Good grief.

3.  They are afraid to try new things.  I mean I have met people who had never in their lives talked to a foreigner (either Japanese-speaking or otherwise) and they were terrified of even talking to me, despite the fact that I was talking to them in Japanese.  One would think that a country that is on the cutting edge of producing the newest technology every year would be willing to try new things as individuals.  However, such is most definitely not the case.  They like to do things like they 've always done them and never rock the boat.

So as you can see, Japanese people are most definitely wimps.  No matter what you might watch on anime or read about as far as historical samurai go, trust me on this one; they are wimps.  :-)

Wow this article really makes me sick.  They basicallly say, "Oh we're injecting human brain sells into animal fetuses but we'll carefully observe them and in the unlikely case that they display any human traits we'll immediately kill them."  That's just sick.  We're playing with the creation of intelligence in other species.  This has gotta be something like the sins for which the antediluvians were destroyed.  My word, what a nightmare.
